EECS_courses.Title: Introduction to Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering
EECS_courses.Description: Introduction to the fields of Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering, including possible careers in both traditional and new emerging areas. Background on both the Electrical Engineering and the Computer Engineering majors, curriculum requirements, specializations, and faculty research interests.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Computational Methods in Electrical and Computer Engineering
EECS_courses.Description: An introduction to computers and structured programming. Binary Data Representation. Hands-on experience with a high-level structured programming language. Introduction to algorithm efficiency. Applications of structured programming in solving engineering problems. Programming laboratory.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Introduction to Programming
EECS_courses.Description: An introduction to computers and programming. Python programming syntax/style, types. Numbers and sequences. Control flow. I/O and errors/exceptions. Function calling, parameter passing, formal arguments, return values. Variable scoping. Programming laboratory.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Computer Systems and C Programming
EECS_courses.Description: Introduction to computing systems. Data representation and operations. Simple logic design. Basic computer organization. Instruction set architecture and assembly language programming. Introduction to C. Functions and recursion, data structures, pointers. Programming laboratory.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Advanced C Programming
EECS_courses.Description: C language programming concepts. Control flow, function calls, recursion. Basic and composite data types, static and dynamic data structures. Program modules and compilation units. Preprocessor macros. C standard libraries.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Software Engineering Project in C Language
EECS_courses.Description: Hands-on experience with the ANSI-C programming language. Medium-sized programming projects, team work. Software specification, documentation, implementation, testing. Definition of data structures and application programming interface. Creation of program modules, linking with external libraries. Rule-based compilation, version control.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Introduction to Digital Systems
EECS_courses.Description: Digital representation of information. Specification, analysis, design and optimization or combinational and sequential logic, register-transfer components and register-transfer systems with datapaths and controllers. Introduction to high-level and algorithmic state-machines and custom processors.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: ICS 31 or EECS 10 or EECS 12 or MAE 10 or ICS 32A
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Introduction to Digital Logic Laboratory
EECS_courses.Description: Introduction to common digital integrated circuits: gates, memory circuits, MSI components. Operating characteristics, specifications, applications. Design of simple combinational and sequential digital systems (arithmetic processors game-playing machines). Construction and debugging techniques using hardware description languages and CAD tools.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: EECS 31 and (EECS 10 or EECS 12 or ICS 32)
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Object-Oriented Systems and Programming
EECS_courses.Description: Primitive types and expressions. The class and method definition. Information hiding and encapsulation. Objects and reference. Overloading. Constructors. Inheritance basics. Programming with inheritance. Dynamic binding and polymorphism. Exception handling. An overview of streams and file input/output. Programming laboratory.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Discrete-Time Signals and Systems
EECS_courses.Description: Analysis of discrete-time linear-time-invariant (DTLTI) systems in the time domain and using z-transforms. Introduction to techniques based on Discrete-Time, Discrete, and Fast Fourier Transforms. Examples of their application to digital signal processing and digital communications.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Engineering Probability
EECS_courses.Description: Sets and set operations; nature of probability, sample spaces, fields of events, probability measures; conditional probability, independence, random variables, distribution functions, density functions, conditional distributions and densities; moments, characteristic functions, random sequences, independent and Markov sequences.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Network Analysis I
EECS_courses.Description: Modeling and analysis of electrical networks. Basic network theorems. Sinusoidal steady state and transient analysis of RLC networks and the impedance concept.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: PHYS 7D and (EECS 10 or EECS 12 or MAE 10 or ICS 31 or CEE 20)
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Network Analysis II
EECS_courses.Description: Laplace transforms, complex frequency, and the s-plane. Network functions and frequency response, including resonance. Bode plots. Two-port network characterization.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: (BME 60B or EECS 10 or EECS 12 or ICS 31 or CEE 20 or MAE 10) and EECS 70A
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Network Analysis I Laboratory
EECS_courses.Description: Laboratory to accompany EECS 70A.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: PHYS 7D and (EECS 10 or EECS 12 or BME 60B or CEE 20 or MAE 10)
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Network Analysis II Laboratory
EECS_courses.Description: Laboratory to accompany EECS 70B. Materials fee.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: (BME 60B or EECS 10 or EECS 12 or ICS 31 or CEE 20 or MAE 10) and EECS 70A
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Introduction to Machine Vision
EECS_courses.Description: The use of digital computers for the analysis of visual scenes; image formation and sensing, color, segmentation, shape estimation, motion, stereo, pattern classification, computer architectures, applications. Computer experiments are used to illustrate fundamental principles.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: System Software
EECS_courses.Description: Multiprogramming, interrupt, processes, kernel, parallelism, critical sections, deadlocks, communication, multiprocessing, multilevel memory management, binding, name management, file systems, protection, resource allocation, scheduling. Experience with concurrent programming, synchronization mechanisms, interprocess communication.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Organization of Digital Computers
EECS_courses.Description: Building blocks and organization of digital computers, the arithmetic, control, and memory units, and input/out devices and interfaces. Microprogramming and microprocessors.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Organization of Digital Computers Laboratory
EECS_courses.Description: Specification and implementation of a processor-based system using a hardware description language such as VHDL. Hands-on experience with design tools including simulation, synthesis, and evaluation using testbenches.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Processor Hardware/Software Interfaces
EECS_courses.Description: Hardware/software interfacing, including memory and bus interfaces, devices, I/O, and compiler code generation/instruction scheduling. Experience microcontroller programming and interfacing. Specific compiler code generation techniques including local variable and register allocations, instruction dependence and scheduling, and code optimization.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science and Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Engineering Data Structures and Algorithms
EECS_courses.Description: Introduces abstract behavior of classes data structures, alternative implementations, informal analysis of time and space efficiency. Also introduces classic algorithms and efficient algorithm design techniques (recursion, divide-and-conquer, branch-and-bound, dynamic programming).
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Introduction to Data Management
EECS_courses.Description: Introduction to the design of databases and the use of database management systems (DBMS) for applications. Topics include entity-relationship modeling for design, relational data model, relational algebra, relational design theory, and Structured Query Language (SQL) programming.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: ICS 33 or EECS 114. ICS 33 with a grade of C or better
EECS_courses.Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Parallel Computer Systems
EECS_courses.Description: General introduction to parallel computing focusing on parallel algorithms and architectures. Parallel models: Flynn's taxonomy, dataflow models. Parallel architectures: systolic arrays, hypercube architecture, shared memory machines, dataflow machines, reconfigurable architectures. Parallel algorithms appropriate to each machine type area also discussed.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
EECS_courses.Description: Introduction of basic concepts in artificial intelligence. Knowledge representation and reasoning, search, planning, declarative programing, problem solving, and data science.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: VLSI
EECS_courses.Description: Design techniques for Very Large Scale Integrated (VLSI) systems and chips. Review CMOS and related process technologies; primitives such as logic gates and larger design blocks; layout; floor planning; design hierarchy, component interfaces; use of associated CAD tools for design.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Fundamentals of Parallel Computing
EECS_courses.Description: Fundamentals of parallel computing, focusing on parallel algorithms and architectures. Topics include design of parallel and I/O efficient algorithms, basics of parallel machine architectures, and current/emerging programming models (shared memory, distributed memory, and accelerators).
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: System Security
EECS_courses.Description: Fundamentals and practices of system security. Topics include cryptographic (encryption, decryption, and message authentication), software vulnerabilities (buffer overflow), network security (layer 2-7 attacks and defenses and PKI), web security (XSS and XSRF), and privacy.

EECS_courses.Title: Introduction to Machine Learning for Engineers
EECS_courses.Description: Introduction to ML with a special focus on engineering applications. Starts with a mathematical background required for ML and covers various models for supervised learning (classification and regression) and unsupervised learning (clustering).
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: EECS 55 and EECS 145 and EECS 12. Recommended: EECS 114.

EECS_courses.Title: Information Retrieval and Web Search
EECS_courses.Description: Introduction to the analysis and design of information retrieval and web search systems. The focus is on methods for representing, indexing, and retrieving textual and multimedia documents, including web pages, images, and videos.

EECS_courses.Title: Real-Time Embedded Systems
EECS_courses.Description: Introduction to the principles of real-time systems and their embedded applications. Topics include scheduling algorithms, real-time kernels, inter-task communication and synchronization, and interfacing with physical devices.

EECS_courses.Title: Interactive and Embedded Media
EECS_courses.Description: Interactive multimedia technology, including digital video, audio, and imaging. Principles and applications of human-computer interaction. Design, implementation, and evaluation of multimedia systems, with an emphasis on embedded and mobile platforms.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: (EECS 112 or CS 152) and EECS 148 and (ICS 45C or EECS 22)

EECS_courses.Title: Computer Graphics
EECS_courses.Description: Algorithms and systems for generating images from 3D models. Topics include graphics hardware, rasterization, geometric transformations, illumination and shading models, texture mapping, ray tracing, and animation.

EECS_courses.Title: Introduction to Digital Integrated Circuits
EECS_courses.Description: Analysis and design of digital integrated circuits. MOS transistor theory. CMOS gate and flip-flop design. Computer-aided design of digital circuits. Introduction to VLSI concepts.

EECS_courses.Title: Digital Integrated Circuits: Submicron CMOS Technology
EECS_courses.Description: Advanced concepts in CMOS digital integrated circuit design. Submicron MOS transistor theory. CMOS logic and memory design. High-performance circuit techniques.

EECS_courses.Title: Linear Integrated Circuits
EECS_courses.Description: Design of linear integrated circuits including operational amplifiers, function generators, active filters, and voltage regulators. Frequency response, feedback, stability, and compensation. Operational amplifier design and characterization.

EECS_courses.Title: Linear Integrated Circuits Laboratory
EECS_courses.Description: Experimental laboratory to accompany EECS 140A. Laboratory experiments based on the design of linear integrated circuits including operational amplifiers, function generators, active filters, and voltage regulators.

EECS_courses.Title: Feedback Control Systems
EECS_courses.Description: Modeling and analysis of feedback control systems. Stability, transient response, and frequency response analysis and design. Root locus, Nyquist, and Bode techniques. State variable feedback and multivariable control systems.

EECS_courses.Title: Microelectronic Devices and Circuits
EECS_courses.Description: Principles of semiconductor devices including diodes, bipolar and field effect transistors. Basic digital and analog circuits and applications. Semiconductor device physics. Integrated circuit fabrication technology.

EECS_courses.Title: Probability and Random Processes for Electrical Engineering
EECS_courses.Description: Random experiments, sample spaces, probability measures. Random variables and vectors, distribution functions, density functions, conditional distributions, independence. Expectations, moments. Random sequences and processes. Autocorrelation, power spectral density. Stationary processes, Gaussian processes.

EECS_courses.Title: Probability and Random Processes for Computer Science
EECS_courses.Description: Random experiments, sample spaces, probability measures. Random variables and vectors, distribution functions, density functions, conditional distributions, independence. Expectations, moments. Random sequences and processes. Autocorrelation, power spectral density. Stationary processes, Gaussian processes.

EECS_courses.Title: Digital Design Principles
EECS_courses.Description: Basic concepts of digital design. Emphasis on combinational logic and sequential system design. Topics include Boolean algebra, minimization techniques, timing diagrams, flip-flops, shift registers, counters, arithmetic circuits, state machines, and CAD tools for digital design.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: (CS 33 or EECS 12 or EECS 20 or ICS 45C) and (MATH 2A or MATH 3A) and (PHYS 7C or PHYS 7D)

EECS_courses.Title: Digital Design Project Laboratory
EECS_courses.Description: Digital design project experience including specifications, architectural design, detailed design, implementation, and testing. The project may involve computer-aided design tools and hardware and software components.

EECS_courses.Title: Senior Design Project I
EECS_courses.Description: Teaches problem definition, detailed design, integration, and testability with teams of students specifying, designing, building, and testing complex systems. Lectures include engineering values, discussions, and ethical ramifications of engineering decisions.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Seniors only. Computer Science Engineering Majors only. Electrical Engineering Majors only. Computer Engineering Majors only.

EECS_courses.Title: Senior Design Project II
EECS_courses.Description: Teaches problem definition, detailed design, integration, and testability with teams of students specifying, designing, building, and testing complex systems. Lectures include engineering values, discussions, and ethical ramifications of engineering decisions. Materials fee.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors only. Electrical Engineering Majors only. Computer Engineering Majors only.

EECS_courses.Title: Introduction to Control Systems
EECS_courses.Description: Modeling, stability, and specifications of feedback control systems. Root locus, Bode plots, Nyquist criteria, and state-space methods for dynamic analysis and design.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: (EECS 10 or EECS 12 or MAE 10 or BME 60B or CEE 20) and EECS 150 and EECS 170B and EECS 170LB
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Control Systems I Laboratory
EECS_courses.Description: Laboratory accompanying EECS 160A. Materials fee.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Power Systems
EECS_courses.Description: Generation, transmission, and use of electrical energy. Fault calculation, protection, stability, and power flow.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Power Systems Laboratory
EECS_courses.Description: Experiments and field trips relevant to studies in power systems. Materials fee.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors only. Electrical Engineering Majors only. Computer Engineering Majors only.

EECS_courses.Title: Industrial and Power Electronics
EECS_courses.Description: Power switching devices, pulse width modulation (PWM) methods, switching converter topologies, control, and magnetics. Materials fee.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Electronics I
EECS_courses.Description: The properties of semiconductors, electronic conduction in solids, the physics and operation principles of semiconductor devices such as diodes and transistors, transistor equivalent circuits, and transistor amplifiers.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Electronics II
EECS_courses.Description: Design and analysis of single-stage amplifiers, biasing circuits, inverters, logic gates, and memory elements based on CMOS transistors.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Electronics III
EECS_courses.Description: Principles of operation, design, and utilization of integrated circuit modules, including multi-stage amplifiers, operational amplifiers, and logic circuits.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Integrated Electronic Circuit Design
EECS_courses.Description: Design and fabrication of modern digital integrated circuits. Fabrication of CMOS process, transistor-level design simulation, functional characteristics of basic digital integrated circuits, and different logic families including the static and dynamic logic, layout, and extraction of digital circuits.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Analog and Communications IC Design
EECS_courses.Description: Advanced topics in design of analog and communications integrated circuits. Topics include: implementation of passive components in integrated circuits; overview of frequency response of amplifiers, bandwidth estimation techniques, high-frequency amplifier design; design of radio-frequency oscillators.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Electronics I Laboratory
EECS_courses.Description: Laboratory accompanying EECS 170A to perform experiments on semiconductor material properties, semiconductor device physics and operation principles, and transistor amplifiers to improve experimental skills and to enhance the understanding of lecture materials.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Electronics II Laboratory
EECS_courses.Description: Laboratory accompanying EECS 170B.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Electronics III Laboratory
EECS_courses.Description: Laboratory accompanying EECS 170C to provide hands-on training in design of digital/analog circuits/subsystems. Materials fee.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Semiconductor Devices
EECS_courses.Description: Metal-semiconductor junctions, diodes, bipolar junction transistors, MOS structures, MOSFETs, CMOS technology, LEDs, and laser diodes.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Materials Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Fundamentals of Solid-State Electronics and Materials
EECS_courses.Description: Physical properties of semiconductors and the roles materials play in device operation. Topics include: crystal structure, phonon vibrations, energy band, transport phenomenon, optical properties and quantum confinement effect essential to the understanding of electronic, optoelectronic and nanodevices.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Microelectromechanical Systems (MEMS)
EECS_courses.Description: Small-scale machines, small-scale phenomena, MEMS fabrication, MEMS CAD tools, MEMS devices and packaging, MEMS testing.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Upper-division students only. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Engineering Electromagnetics I
EECS_courses.Description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, and electromagnetic fields: solutions to problems in engineering applications; transmission lines, Maxwell's equations and phasors, plane wave propagation, reflection, and transmission.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Engineering Electromagnetics II
EECS_courses.Description: Time-varying electromagnetic fields, plane waves, polarization, guidance of waves like rectangular waveguides and microstrips, optical fibers resonant cavities, skin effects and losses, spherical waves, radiation and reception of waves, antenna basics.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Monolithic Microwave Integrated Circuit (MMIC) Analysis and Design
EECS_courses.Description: Design of microwave amplifiers including low-noise amplifiers, multiple stage amplifiers, power amplifiers, and introduction to broadband amplifiers. The goal is to provide the basic knowledge for the design of microwave amplifiers ranging from wireless system to radar system.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Optical Electronics
EECS_courses.Description: Photodiodes and optical detection, photometry and radiometry, geometric optics, lens theory, imaging system, EM wave propagation, optical waveguides and fibers, heterojunction structures, laser theory, semiconductor lasers, and optical transmission system.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS_courses.Title: Special Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering
EECS_courses.Description: Studies special topics in selected areas of Electrical and Computer Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

EECS_courses.Title: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Internship
EECS_courses.Description: Students majoring in EECS may receive credit for an approved internship, working at a company under the supervision of an industry mentor and a faculty advisor. Enables students to gain valuable experience in a professional setting and enhance their skills.
EECS_courses.Repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.

EECS_courses.Title: Group Study
EECS_courses.Description: Group study of selected topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering.
EECS_courses.Repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Upper-division students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Individual Study
EECS_courses.Description: For undergraduate Engineering majors in supervised but independent reading, research, or design. Students taking Individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.
EECS_courses.Repeatability: May be taken for credit for 8 units.

EECS_courses.Title: Individual Study
EECS_courses.Description: For undergraduate Engineering majors in supervised but independent reading, research, or design. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.
EECS_courses.Repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

EECS_courses.Title: Techniques in Medical Imaging: X-ray, Nuclear, and NMR Imaging
EECS_courses.Description: Ionizing radiation, planar and tomographic radiographic and nuclear imaging, magnetism, NMR, MRI imaging.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Digital Image Processing
EECS_courses.Description: Pixel-level digital image representation and elementary operations; Fourier and other unitary transforms; compression, enhancement, filtering, and restoration; laboratory experience is provided.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Digital Image Processing
EECS_courses.Description: Pixel-level digital image representation and elementary operations; Fourier and other unitary transforms; compression, enhancement, filtering, and restoration; laboratory experience is provided.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Personalized Medical Devices
EECS_courses.Description: Introduces students to fundamental aspects of medical devices and discusses therapeutic as well as diagnostic devices. Basic aspects of microfluidics and biology critical to personalized medical systems are studied. Typical FDA approval pathways for medical devices are presented.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Master of Engineering students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Advanced System Software
EECS_courses.Description: Study of operating systems including interprocess communication, scheduling, resource management, concurrency, reliability, validation, protection and security, and distributed computing support. System software design languages and modeling analysis.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Advanced System Software
EECS_courses.Description: Study of operating systems including interprocess communication, scheduling, resource management, concurrency, reliability, validation, protection and security, and distributed computing support. System software design languages and modeling analysis.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: Recommended: Undergraduate-level knowledge of system software (e.g. EECS 111) and organization of digital computers (e.g. UCI EECS 112)
EECS_courses.Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Computer Architecture
EECS_courses.Description: Problems in hardware, firmware (microprogram), and software. Computer architecture for resource sharing, real-time applications, parallelism, microprogramming, and fault tolerance. Various architectures based on cost/performance and current technology.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Computer Architecture
EECS_courses.Description: Problems in hardware, firmware (microprogram), and software. Computer architecture for resource sharing, real-time applications, parallelism, microprogramming, and fault tolerance. Various architectures based on cost/performance and current technology.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: Recommended: Undergraduate-level knowledge of organization of digital computers (e.g. EECS 112 and EECS 112L)
EECS_courses.Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
EECS_courses.Description: Computer algorithms from a practical standpoint. Algorithms for symbolic and numeric problems such as sorting, searching, graphs, and network flow. Analysis includes algorithm time and space complexity.

EECS_courses.Title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
EECS_courses.Description: Computer algorithms from a practical standpoint. Algorithms for symbolic and numeric problems such as sorting, searching, graphs, and network flow. Analysis includes algorithm time and space complexity.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Advanced Application of Algorithms
EECS_courses.Description: Medium-sized group and individual programming project. Topics include specification requirements documentation, practical implementation of algorithms, and testing/verification of design.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: Recommended: Undergraduate course work in engineering data structures and algorithms.

EECS_courses.Title: VLSI System Design
EECS_courses.Description: Overview of integrated fabrication, circuit simulation, basic device physics, device layout, timing; MOS logic design; layout generation, module generation, techniques for very large scale integrated circuit design.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: VLSI System Design
EECS_courses.Description: Overview of integrated fabrication, circuit simulation, basic device physics, device layout, timing; MOS logic design; layout generation, module generation, techniques for very large scale integrated circuit design.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: Recommended: Undergraduate-level knowledge of organization of digital computers (e.g. EECS 112)
EECS_courses.Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Advanced Digital Signal Processing Architecture
EECS_courses.Description: Study the latest DSP architectures for applications in communication (wired and wireless) and multimedia processing. Emphasis given to understanding the current design techniques and to evaluate the performance, power, and application domain of the latest DSP processors.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: EECS 213P. EECS 213P with a grade of B- or better
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Engineering students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Topics in Computer Engineering
EECS_courses.Description: New research results in computer engineering.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Embedded System Modeling
EECS_courses.Description: Computational models for embedded systems. System-level specification and description languages. Concepts of hardware/software co-design. Simulation and validation techniques. Hardware/software partitioning and scheduling. Case studies.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Topics in Computer Systems and Software
EECS_courses.Description: New research results in computer systems and software.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Automated Reasoning and Theorem Proving
EECS_courses.Description: Studies the development of automated reasoning tools (e.g., automated theorem provers, model checkers) and their applications in formal verification, program analysis, and synthesis. The course will cover topics including logic and proof techniques, SAT and SMT solvers, model checking, and synthesis. Students will develop hands-on experience in using state-of-the-art automated reasoning tools.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: CS 170 or EECS 127 or consent of instructor.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Special Topics in Verification, Testing, and Debugging
EECS_courses.Description: Covers advanced techniques for the formal verification, testing, and debugging of software systems. Topics may include formal specification and verification, testing methodologies, dynamic analysis, and automatic bug fixing. The course will emphasize both theoretical foundations and practical applications, with a focus on hands-on projects using state-of-the-art tools.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: CS 162 or CS 169 or CS 170 or equivalent background in algorithms, and CS 164 or equivalent background in programming languages and systems, or consent of instructor.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Special Topics in Computer Systems
EECS_courses.Description: Advanced topics in computer systems. May be repeated for credit with permission of instructor.

EECS_courses.Title: Neuromorphic Engineering
EECS_courses.Description: Neuromorphic engineering principles and techniques for building efficient and adaptive computing systems. Topics include principles of neural computation, analog and mixed-signal circuits and systems for implementing neural models, learning algorithms and hardware implementations, and applications to real-time sensing and processing.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: EECS 170 or equivalent. Basic background in analog and digital circuits.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Topics in Circuits and Systems
EECS_courses.Description: Special topics in circuits and systems.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Topics in Machine Learning Hardware
EECS_courses.Description: Focus on the development of hardware for machine learning. Topics include digital and analog hardware for implementing machine learning algorithms, with applications to neural networks, deep learning, and other learning paradigms.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Special Topics in Digital Systems and Integrated Circuit Design
EECS_courses.Description: Advanced topics in digital systems and integrated circuit design.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Advanced Digital VLSI Design
EECS_courses.Description: Advanced topics in digital VLSI design. Topics include advanced CMOS circuits, low-power VLSI design, clocking strategies, and design for manufacturability.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Title: Topics in Hardware and Embedded System Security
EECS_courses.Description: Focus on the design and analysis of secure hardware and embedded systems. Topics include hardware security primitives, side-channel attacks, secure processor architectures, and hardware-software co-design for security.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.

EECS_courses.Description: Advanced topics in wireless communications systems.

EECS_courses.Title: Advanced Algorithm Design and Analysis
EECS_courses.Description: Advanced design and analysis of algorithms. Topics include advanced data structures, advanced graph algorithms, approximation algorithms, randomized algorithms, and online algorithms. Advanced techniques for the design and analysis of algorithms, including advanced data structures, approximation algorithms, randomized algorithms, and online algorithms. Applications to optimization, network algorithms, and computational biology.
EECS_courses.Prerequisite: EECS 168 or equivalent, and EECS 169 or equivalent, or consent of instructor.
EECS_courses.Restriction: Graduate students only.
